      "text": "Hi Ms. ___. I’m one of the medicine residents. You came in from the dialysis unit after feeling faint, short of breath, and sweaty while you were on your way to see your kidney doctor. Can you tell me in your own words what happened today and over the last week or so?",

    {
      "turn_id": 2,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:17",
      "text": "I was walking to my appointment and in the lobby I suddenly felt really short of breath, lightheaded, and cold and sweaty. It’s been happening a lot. This past week I get short of breath just walking to the bathroom. I almost passed out in the shower last week. No chest pain, just feel like I might faint.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 3,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:20",
      "text": "Thank you. In the emergency room your blood pressure was low but you were thinking clearly and your oxygen level was good on room air. They gave you an IV antibiotic dose and drew blood cultures, and your chest X-ray didn’t show any pneumonia or fluid in the lungs. Your EKG showed a normal rhythm. Does that match what you were told?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RAD#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 4,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:21",
      "text": "Yeah, they said my pressure was low but that happens with dialysis. They did an X-ray and heart test and said they looked okay. I don’t remember all the details.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 5,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:24",
      "text": "You also mentioned some other symptoms—left-sided headaches you’ve been treating with Tylenol and Percocet, some nausea with a couple of episodes of vomiting a few nights ago, and right knee and thigh pain that’s been getting worse over weeks. Is that still going on now?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 6,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:25",
      "text": "Yes, the headache on the left is pretty constant, kind of achy. I’ve been taking Tylenol and Percocet around the clock. I had nausea and threw up twice a few nights ago but not today. My right leg still aches, especially the knee and thigh.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 7,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:28",
      "text": "I see. I also see in your chart that you have HIV and are on your medications, you’re on hemodialysis three times a week through the catheter in your left chest, and you’ve had trigeminal neuralgia or shingles on the right side of your face with chronic pain and eye involvement. You also have a history of atrial fibrillation and peripheral neuropathy. Is that all correct?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000003", "DX#000008", "DX#000009"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 8,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:29",
      "text": "Yes, I have HIV and I go to clinic for that. I’m on dialysis Monday, Wednesday, Friday. The right side of my face and eye have hurt since I had shingles there. And they told me I had an irregular heartbeat before. My feet and legs tingle a lot too.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "DX#000002", "DX#000008", "DX#000009"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 9,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:33",
      "text": "On exam right now your blood pressure is about 98 over 60, your heart rate is around 100, you’re breathing comfortably with good oxygen, and your lungs sound mostly clear with just faint crackles at the bases. Your heart sounds regular, your belly is soft and not tender, and your neurologic exam is normal. You do look a bit dry in the mouth. We’ll admit you to the medicine floor, keep you on the monitor, and check more labs to look for causes of the low blood pressure and shortness of breath.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "POE#000005", "POE#000003"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 10,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:34",
      "text": "Okay. I just don’t want to pass out again. Will you figure out why my pressure keeps dropping?",
      "evidence_eids": []
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 11,
      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "H+00:36",
      "text": "That’s our goal. We’re thinking about volume shifts from dialysis, possible adrenal gland problems, heart rhythm issues, or infection. We’ll keep you on telemetry, get an echocardiogram of your heart, and do blood tests including cortisol and repeat chemistries. We’ll also hold your diltiazem for now since it can lower blood pressure.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "POE#000005", "POE#000013", "RX#000018"]
    },

      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+01:30",
      "text": "Ms. ___, I’m your nurse on the floor. Your vitals right now are stable—temperature 97.7, blood pressure 98 over 60, heart rate 100, breathing 18, oxygen 98% on room air. I’m going to start your scheduled medications, including your HIV meds, dialysis-related meds, and eye ointment, and I’ll draw some morning labs a bit earlier because the team wants to check your calcium and kidney numbers.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001", "RX#000001", "RX#000003", "RX#000004", "RX#000005", "RX#000006", "RX#000007", "RX#000009", "RX#000011", "POE#000014"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 13,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "H+01:32",
      "text": "Alright. I’m okay with the meds. My head still hurts on the left though. Can I get something for that?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 14,
      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "H+01:35",
      "text": "You have acetaminophen ordered as needed and also oxycodone if the pain is more severe. I’ll bring you some Tylenol first and see if that helps, and I’ll let the team know your headache is still pretty bad.",
      "evidence_eids": ["PHARM#000002", "PHARM#000016", "RX#000012", "RX#000015"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 15,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:30",
      "text": "Good morning, Ms. ___. I’m the attending physician. I’ve reviewed your labs from early this morning. Your calcium level is quite high at 12.7, your phosphate is 5.1, and your kidney numbers are elevated as expected with your end-stage renal disease. Your blood counts show a normal hemoglobin and platelets, with slightly large red blood cells. We think the high calcium may be contributing to your fatigue, nausea, and possibly your low blood pressure.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000012", "LAB#000017", "LAB#000014", "LAB#000020", "LAB#000001", "LAB#000002", "LAB#000005", "DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 16,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:32",
      "text": "High calcium? I didn’t know that could make me feel this tired and sick. Is that from my kidneys?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 17,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:35",
      "text": "In people on dialysis, high calcium can be related to overactive parathyroid glands, adrenal issues, or, less commonly, cancers. Your parathyroid hormone level is elevated at 286, which fits with long-standing kidney disease, and your alkaline phosphatase is normal, which is somewhat reassuring. We’ll also check vitamin D and a parathyroid hormone–related protein, and we’ll use dialysis to help bring the calcium down. We’re continuing your cinacalcet to help control the parathyroid overactivity.",
      "evidence_eids": ["LAB#000023", "LAB#000021", "PHARM#000007", "RX#000006", "DS#000001", "POE#000039", "POE#000049", "POE#000050", "POE#000066", "POE#000067"]

      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:37",
      "text": "Okay. As long as it comes down. I’ve also been really nauseated sometimes. Is that from the calcium too?",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 19,
      "speaker": "ATTENDING",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:40",
      "text": "It could be. Hypercalcemia often causes nausea and vomiting. We’re giving you anti-nausea medicine like ondansetron as needed, and we’ll also get liver tests and an ultrasound of your abdomen to make sure there’s no gallbladder or liver problem contributing.       "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 09:42",

    {

      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 10:17",
      "text": "Alright. I just want to know why I keep almost passing out. I’m scared it’ll happen at home again.",

      "speaker": "NURSE",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 13:30",
      "text": "Ms. ___, radiology is ready for your head CT because of your headaches. We’ll take you down now. It’s a quick scan and doesn’t use contrast.",

      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 13:31",
      "text": "Okay. My head has been really bothering me, so I hope it shows what’s going on.",
      "evidence_eids": ["DS#000001"]
    },
    {
      "turn_id": 25,
      "speaker": "CONSULT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 16:30",
      "text": "Ms. ___, I’m from the radiology team. Your head CT shows no bleeding, no mass, and no stroke. There are some heavy calcifications along the membranes in your brain, which we often see in people with long-standing kidney disease, but nothing acute or dangerous.",

    {
      "turn_id": 26,
      "speaker": "PATIENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 16:32",
      "text": "So no tumor or bleeding? That’s a relief. But why does my head still hurt?",

    {

      "speaker": "RESIDENT",
      "relative_time": "HospitalDay1 16:40",
      "text": "We’re glad the CT is normal. Your headaches could be from migraine, tension, neuropathic pain, or even related to your HIV medications. We briefly tried carbamazepine this morning for possible trigeminal neuralgia, but we stopped it the same day. For now we’ll continue to treat your pain with oxycodone as needed and reassess as an outpatient for migraine-specific medications if needed.",

      "speaker": "PATIENT",
